da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (16:20): +so if you sent a ping... from one node to another (on the other network) it would ping.... as the switch would look at layer 2 frame get the dest mac and forward to relevant port
31f0cd5776fda31893bae4a109bcde93 (16:21): +from the 192 to the 172 network you mean... ?
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (16:21): +yep
31f0cd5776fda31893bae4a109bcde93 (16:21): +then you need routing from x to y
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (16:21): +as switch wouldnt care about the layer 3 addressing
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (16:21): +it would look at layer 2 find mac address and check it arp table forward to relevant port

da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (16:23): +think this way...

00f39836d182ebb443457e1c0a8aaf65 (16:23): -The local machine that you're pinging from doesn't know anything about 172.. Its not directly conencted and it doesn't have a route, it'll think you're crazy.
31f0cd5776fda31893bae4a109bcde93 (16:23): +no need.. the host that you ping from will try to contact your default gw

da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (16:33): +basically local machine checks address..if not is local network... it only forwards too GW... which thenc checks packet at layer 3
31f0cd5776fda31893bae4a109bcde93 (16:34): +you can add an extra IP to the host in network x so that host will be in network x and in network y
31f0cd5776fda31893bae4a109bcde93 (16:34): +only add an ip/ and netmask for network x no extra gw.
